q: What are the symptoms of a perforated eardrum?
a: Symptoms of a perforated eardrum usually include hearing loss, ringing or buzzing sound in the ear (tinnitus), earache or ear pain, itching in the ear, and clear fluid, blood, or pus leaking from the ear.

q: When should I seek urgent medical help for a possible perforated eardrum?
a: You should ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 if you have sudden hearing loss in one or both ears, hearing loss along with other symptoms like earache or discharge from the ear, or if your hearing has been getting worse over the last few days or weeks.

q: How long does a perforated eardrum usually take to heal?
a: A perforated eardrum usually gets better on its own within 2 months and your hearing returns to normal. However, if your symptoms have not started to improve after a few weeks, it is advisable to consult your GP.

q: Can a perforated eardrum be treated with antibiotics?
a: Yes, a GP may prescribe antibiotics if you have an ear infection or to prevent an ear infection while your eardrum heals. However, it is important to consult your GP for proper evaluation and treatment.

q: Is surgery required to repair a perforated eardrum?
a: Sometimes, surgery to repair the eardrum (myringoplasty) may be needed if the eardrum is not healing by itself. If your symptoms have not improved after a few weeks, it is advisable to consult your GP for further evaluation.

q: What can I do to help heal a perforated eardrum?
a: You can take painkillers like paracetamol or ibuprofen to ease pain. Putting a piece of cotton wool covered in petroleum jelly in your outer ear when washing your hair can help prevent water from getting in. It is important to remember not to go swimming or get your ear wet until your eardrum heals.

q: Can I put cotton buds or eardrops in my ear if I have a perforated eardrum?
a: It is generally not recommended to put anything inside your ear, such as cotton buds or eardrops, unless specifically recommended by a doctor. It is best to consult with a healthcare professional for proper guidance and treatment.

q: Is it safe to fly with a perforated eardrum?
a: It is generally safe to fly with a perforated eardrum. However, if you have had surgery to repair the eardrum (myringoplasty), it is important to wait until you are told it is safe to fly.

q: Where can I find more information about myringoplasty surgery?
a: You can find more information about myringoplasty surgery on the ENT UK website.
